data.name: Custom Coercion
data.description:
Everyone knows the rules of coercion can be a little tricky in JavaScript, so in this exercise, we're going to write our own rules of coercion to get a deeper understanding of how/when values change. We will only be working with primitive types: Number, String, Boolean, Null, and Undefined. 

For this Kata, we will only use the +operator. These are the rules:

1. Null and Undefined coerce to 0, "", or false, respective to the other value
1a. If Null and Undefined are + together, coerce to Null
2. + with a boolean type must stay boolean: true + 5 === true, false + 0 === false. Determine these with truthy/falsy values
3. If a string is actually a number (ie: "15") then treat it as such, unless the other value is objectively a string (ie: "cat")
4. NaN will not be a starting value
